required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Long-term Safety Study of the GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder
clinical_study.official_title: GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder Post-Approval Study

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of the GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder in the treatment of ostium secundum atrial septal defects (ASDs).

detailed_description.textblock: The GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder is an approved medical device indicated for the transcatheter closure of atrial septal defects (ASDs). The purpose of this study is to evaluate the long-term safety and efficacy of the GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder in the treatment of ostium secundum atrial septal defects (ASDs). This is an FDA Condition of Approval Study. All subjects enrolled in this study will be followed for long-term safety and efficacy of the occluder device through 5 years.

primary_outcome.description: A calculation of the proportion of subjects with clinically successful defect closure as determined by the site at 1, 3, and 5 years postprocedure. Clinical Success is a composite measure of safety and efficacy evaluated at the 12-, 36-, and 60-month post-procedure evaluations and is defined as absence of: Any major device/procedure adverse event Repeat procedure to the target ASD. Repeat procedures were considered major adverse events and are included in the major adverse event group. Clinically significant leak at the follow-up visit

A calculation of the proportion of subjects with clinically successful defect closure as determined by the site at 1, 3, and 5 years postprocedure. Clinical Success is a composite measure of safety and efficacy evaluated at the 12-, 36-, and 60-month post-procedure evaluations and is defined as absence of: Any major device/procedure adverse event Repeat procedure to the target ASD. Repeat procedures were considered major adverse events and are included in the major adverse event group. Clinically significant leak at the follow-up visit

A calculation of the proportion of subjects with clinically successful defect closure as determined by the site at 1, 3, and 5 years postprocedure. Clinical Success is a composite measure of safety and efficacy evaluated at the 12-, 36-, and 60-month post-procedure evaluations and is defined as absence of: Any major device/procedure adverse event Repeat procedure to the target ASD. Repeat procedures were considered major adverse events and are included in the major adverse event group. Clinically significant leak at the follow-up visit
A calculation of the proportion of subjects experiencing one or more major device or procedure related adverse event(s) at 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 years post procedure.

arm_group.description: Subjects who received a GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder

intervention.description: Percutaneous transcatheter closure of ostium secundum atrial septal defects (ASDs)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ASD less than or equal to 18 mm.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Conditions that would confound treatment of ASD or complicate distinguishing onset of adverse events.
- Unable to accommodate device delivery catheter.

clinical_study.keyword: atrial septal defect, septal occluder, HELEX

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Data was combined from the following sources: (1) Continued Access Study of the GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder (PMA Subjects HLX 03-01 – last 87 non-training subjects) and (2) subjects implanted with the HELEX device enrolled in the Post-Approval Study of the GORE® HELEX® Septal Occluder (n=128). The total number of subjects enrolled is 215.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Only subjects with a successful implant of the device were included from each study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Gore has the right to review disclosures, requesting a delay of less than 90 days. Each investigator will postpone single center publications until after disclosure of multi-center data, less than 12 months from study completion/termination at all participating sites.
